description.description: A brief description of the team.

createdAt.description: Timestamp indicating when the team was created.

Player.title: Player
Player.description: Represents a player in a cricket team.

dateOfBirth.description: Date of birth of the player.

role.description: Role of the player (e.g., Batsman, Bowler, All-rounder).

isRetired.description: Indicates whether the player is retired.

Match.title: Match
Match.description: Represents a cricket match between two teams.

team1Id.description: Reference to Team (first team in the match).

team2Id.description: Reference to Team (second team in the match).

matchDate.description: Date and time the match was played.

tossWinnerId.description: Reference to Team (team that won the toss).

tossDecision.description: Decision made by the toss winner (Bat or Bowl).

winningTeamId.description: Reference to Team. (winning team, null if the match is still in progress, or tied)

Score.title: Score
Score.description: Represents the score of a specific match for a team.

id.description: Unique identifier for the score record.

runs.description: Total runs scored by the team in the match.

wickets.description: Total wickets taken by the team in the match.

wides.description: Number of wide balls bowled by the team.

noBalls.description: Number of no balls bowled by the team.

definition.description: Stores team information.  The 'teamId' is used to uniquely identify each team.

params.name: teamId
params.description: The unique identifier of the team.

definition.description: Stores player information. The 'playerId' is used to uniquely identify each player.

params.name: playerId
params.description: The unique identifier of the player.

definition.description: Stores match information. The 'matchId' is used to uniquely identify each match.

params.name: matchId
params.description: The unique identifier of the match.

firestore.reasoning: The Firestore structure is designed with a flat hierarchy for core entities (Teams, Players, Matches) to simplify queries and align with the application's data access patterns. This structure avoids complex subcollection queries for primary data, enhancing performance and scalability. Security rules will be managed at the collection level, providing clear and manageable access control.
